p: Univariate analyses showed that the younger participants (18–50 years n = 163) were more likely to receive information regarding chikunguya via social media (18.4% vs 5.7%, p <0.001), internet (24.5% vs 6.9%, p <0.001) and family/friends (49.7% vs 35.1%, p = 0.01) compared to the older participants (≥ 51 years n = 174)( S4 Table). In the context of dengue, the younger participants (18–50 years n = 161) were more likely to receive information via their GPs (22.4% vs 10,1%, p = 0.003), social media (13.7% vs 3.6%, p <0.001), and internet (19.3% vs 6.5%, p <0.001) compared to the older participants (≥ 51 years n = 168)( Table 1). Futhermore, women (n = 246) were more likely to receive information regarding chikunguya from the internet (18.3% vs 7.7%, p = 0.02) and family/friends (46.7% vs 29.7%, p <0.001) compared to men (n = 91)( S4 Table).
